Abstract

We investigate the condensation of charged K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson and neutral KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson in dense neutron star matter. Calculations are performed in relativistic mean field models in which both the baryon-baryon and (anti)kaon-baryon interactions are mediated by meson exchange. It is found that KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation is quite sensitive to the antikaon optical potential and depends more strongly on the nucleonic equation of state. For moderate values of antikaon potential and a rather stiff equation of state, a significant region of maximum mass star will contain KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson. The critical density of KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation is always higher than that of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation. With the appearance of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates, pairs of p-K-ğ‘superscriptğ¾italic-p ADDOP:minus italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp-K^{-} and n-KÂ¯0ğ‘›superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0italic-n ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn-\bar{K}^{0} are produced with equal proportion leading to a perfectly symmetric matter of nucleons and antikaons in neutron stars. Along with K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate, KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate makes the equation of state much softer resulting in smaller maximum mass stars compared to the case without any condensate.

I Introduction

The study of dense matter in laboratories reveals many new and interesting results. There is a growing interplay between the physics of dense matter and the physics of compact objects [1, 2]. The composition and structure of a neutron star primarily depends on the nature of strong interaction. The equation of state of neutron star matter encompasses a wide range of densities, from the density of iron nucleus at the starâ€™s surface to several times the normal nuclear matter density encountered in the core. Since the chemical potentials of nucleons and leptons increase rapidly with density in the stars interior, several novel phases with large strangeness fraction may appear. Among these possibilities, hyperon formation is quite a robust mechanism. This is possible when the neutron chemical potential becomes sufficiently large so that the neutrons at their Fermi surfaces can decay into hyperons via weak strangeness non-conserving interactions. The threshold densities for hyperon formation strongly depend on the nuclear equation of state [3, 4].

In recent years considerable interest has grown in the study of the properties of kaons, Kğ¾italic-KK, and antikaons, KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K}, in dense nuclear matter and in neutron star matter. Within a chiral Sâ¢Uâ¢(3)LÃ—Sâ¢Uâ¢(3)Rğ‘†ğ‘ˆsubscript3ğ¿ğ‘†ğ‘ˆsubscript3ğ‘…italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSU(3)_{L}\times SU(3)_{R} Lagrangian, it was demonstrated by Kaplan and Nelson [5] that a negatively charged antikaon K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} may undergo Bose-Einstein condensation in dense baryonic matter formed in heavy ion collisions. It was further predicted in the chiral perturbation theory that a K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensed phase may form in the core of neutron stars [6, 7, 8] in consonance with kaon-nucleon scattering data [9] and K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} atomic data [10]. In these chiral Lagrangians, the (anti)kaons are directly coupled to nucleons. The strongly attractive K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-}-nucleon interaction increases with density lowering the effective mass mK*superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ¾italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endm_{K}^{*} of the antikaons. Consequently, the in-medium energy of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson, Ï‰K-subscriptğœ”superscriptğ¾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}}, decreases and sğ‘ italic-ss-wave K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation sets in when Ï‰K-subscriptğœ”superscriptğ¾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}} equals to the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} chemical potential Î¼K-subscriptğœ‡superscriptğ¾italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{K^{-}} which, in turn, is equal to the electron chemical potential Î¼esubscriptğœ‡ğ‘’italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{e} for a cold catalyzed (neutrino-free) neutron star matter. The typical critical density for K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation in nucleons-only star matter is about (3-4)â¢n034subscriptğ‘›0OPEN:( NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 CLOSE:) italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(3-4)n_{0}, where n0subscriptğ‘›0italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{0} is the normal nuclear matter density. The exact value, however, depends on the model used, i.e. on the nucleonic equation of state and on the parameters employed, especially on the depth of the attractive K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential. The net effect of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation in neutron star matter is that K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} replaces electrons in maintaining charge neutrality and the energy of the condensate is lowered because of strongly attractive interactions between nucleons and K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} mesons. Due to the softening of the equation of state the masses of the stars are reduced in presence of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate [7, 11, 12, 13, 14]. It was also found that in presence of hyperons, K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation was delayed to higher density, and may not even exist in maximum mass stars. Protoneutron (newly born and neutrino rich) stars with K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate was shown to have maximum masses larger than those of cold catalyzed (old and neutrino free) stars - a reversal from ordinary nucleons-only star. These stars may undergo supernovae explosion and then could collapse to small mass black holes during deleptonization [15].

The situation for kaons is however quite different. Theoretical investigations based on Nambu-ADDOP:minus-Jona-Lasinio model [16], chiral perturbation theory [9], and one-boson-exchange model [12, 13] yield a repulsive optical potential for K+superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{+} in nuclear medium. Therefore, K+superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{+} condensation is expected to be forbidden in neutron stars.

In the traditional meson-exchange picture [17], (anti)kaons and baryons interact via the exchange of Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma, Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega, and ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho mesons. In addition to the decrease of mK*superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ¾italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endm_{K}^{*} with density here, the energy Ï‰K-subscriptğœ”superscriptğ¾italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}} is lowered since K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson experiences attractive vector Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega-meson potential due to G-parity of antikaons. In contrast, the isovector ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho-meson field is repulsive for K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and inhibits K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation delaying it to higher densities. In neutron stars at densities above normal nuclear matter values, most of the protons convert into neutrons by inverse Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta-decay since it is energetically favorable to posses a small number of electrons. The ratio of electrons to nucleons which is again equal to the proton fraction due to charge neutrality is typically Ye=Ypâ‰ˆ0.1-0.15subscriptğ‘Œğ‘’subscriptğ‘Œğ‘0.10.15italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.15Y_{e}=Y_{p}\approx 0.1-0.15. Therefore, neutron star matter is highly asymmetric and quite distinct from ordinary symmetric nuclear matter. This suggests that the ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho-meson field should have a strong repulsive effect on K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. On the other hand, the ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho-meson field induces an attractive field for KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson which is an isodoublet partner of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. The critical density for sğ‘ italic-ss-wave neutral KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson condensation is governed by the condition Ï‰KÂ¯0=0subscriptğœ”superscriptÂ¯ğ¾00italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\omega_{\bar{K}^{0}}=0, and should depend sensitively on the equation of state (EOS). Using variational chain summation method with two-nucleon and three-nucleon interactions, Akmal et al. [18] recently predicted a neutral pion condensation phase transition in neutron star matter at a density of âˆ¼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. So far no calculation of neutral KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation and its impact on the gross properties of neutron stars has been performed. In this paper, we investigate the effect of antikaon condensation with more emphasize on KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate on the constitution and structure of neutron star matter in the standard meson exchange model. For this purpose, we employ the usual relativistic mean field Lagrangian [17] for baryons interacting via meson exchanges and includes also the self-interaction of the mesons. The antikaons are treated in the same footing as the baryons which interact by the exchange of the same mesons. For the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson, the Lagrangian density of Ref. [14] is used, and it is extended to include the KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson. We shall demonstrate within this model that, apart from the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson (as already studied in Ref. [12, 13, 14]), the KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate may also exist inside a neutron star and has a significant influence on the star properties. We shall also show that the threshold densities for the antikaon condensates are quite sensitive to the poorly known high density regime of the equation of state.

The paper is organized as follows. In section II we describe the relativistic mean field (RMF) model of strong interactions. The relevant equations for neutron star matter with antikaon condensate are summarized in this model. In section III the parameters of the model are discussed and effects of antikaon condensates in neutron star matter are presented. Section IV is devoted to summary and conclusions.

In the mean field approximation (MFA) adopted here, the meson fields are replaced by their mean values and the baryon currents by those generated in the presence of the mean meson fields. For a uniform and static matter within MFA, only the time-like components of the vector fields, and the isospin 3-component of ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho-meson field have non-vanishing values. In the present calculation we consider antikaon condensation as a second order phase transition. In principle in neutron star matter with two conserved charges, baryon and electric charge, the condensation can also be treated as a first order phase transition [14]. In this situation, the star would have at low density a normal phase of baryons and leptons followed by a mixed phase of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensate and baryons, and possibly a pure K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensed phase at a higher density. However in the present situation this would be more complicated as K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} have to be treated as two separate phases, and especially when the threshold density of one condensate may be reached in the mixed phase of nucleons and the other condensate. Treatment of such a triple phase would be numerically very involved and is postponed to a future publication.

III Results and discussions

In the effective field theoretic approach adopted here, three distinct sets of coupling constants for nucleons, kaons, and hyperons associated with the exchange of Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma, Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega, and ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho mesons are required. The nucleon-meson coupling constants generated by reproducing the nuclear matter saturation properties are taken from Glendenning and Moszkowski of Ref. [20]. This set is referred to as GM1 and listed in Table I.

Let us now determine the kaon-meson coupling constants. According to the quark and isospin counting rule, the vector coupling constants are given by

gÏ‰â¢K=13â¢gÏ‰â¢Nâ€ƒâ€‚andâ€ƒâ€‚gÏâ¢K=gÏâ¢N.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘”ğœ”ğ¾13subscriptğ‘”ğœ”ğ‘andsubscriptğ‘”ğœŒğ¾subscriptğ‘”ğœŒğ‘italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end and italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-rho italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-rho italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.g_{\omega K}=\frac{1}{3}g_{\omega N}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}{\rm and}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}g_{% \rho K}=g_{\rho N}~{}. (21)

The scalar coupling constant is obtained from the real part of the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential at normal nuclear matter density

UKÂ¯â¢(n0)=-gÏƒâ¢Kâ¢Ïƒ-gÏ‰â¢Kâ¢Ï‰0.subscriptğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ¾subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘”ğœğ¾ğœsubscriptğ‘”ğœ”ğ¾subscriptğœ”0italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-sigma ADDOP:minus italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-omega italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.U_{\bar{K}}\left(n_{0}\right)=-g_{\sigma K}\sigma-g_{\omega K}\omega_{0}~{}. The negative sign in the vector meson potential is due to G-parity. The critical density of KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} condensation should therefore strongly depend on the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} optical potential. Recent fits [1, 21, 22] to the K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} atomic data indicate a strong attractive potential in dense matter. More recently, in high energy heavy ion collisions enhanced subthreshold K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} production with a steep spectral slope was found [23]. In a simplified model this may be interpreted as a strong K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} attraction in nuclear matter. On the other hand, available K-â¢Nsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-NK^{-}N scattering length suggests a repulsive interaction. Apart from the KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical potential depth, the critical densities for antikaon condensation depend sensitively on the nuclear equation of state at high density. The GM1 set is obtained from a Walecka-type Lagrangian with a self-interaction term for the scalar meson. Because of the linear density-dependence of the vector Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega-meson field, it was found that the vector potential overestimates the relativistic Bruckner-Hartree-Fock (RBHF) results at high densities. We now briefly consider the case when hyperons are allowed in addition to nucleons. At higher densities when the Fermi energy of nucleons exceeds the effective mass of a hyperon minus its associated interaction, the conversion of nucleons to hyperon is energetically favorable. Since the conversion of nucleons to hyperons relieves the Fermi pressure of nucleons, the equation of state is softened. The standard mean field model used in the hyperon sector was found [39] to be inadequate to describe the strongly attractive hyperon-hyperon interaction observed in double Î›Î›Lambda\Lambda-hypernuclei. Since the core of a neutron star can be hyperon-rich [4], the hyperon-hyperon interaction is expected to be important. In this paper, we have employed the relativistic mean field model where the nucleon-meson coupling constants are fitted to certain bulk properties at normal nuclear matter density. The model is then extended to high density regime to investigate the effects of antikaon condensation. The underlying assumption in the RMF models is that the meson field operators in the Euler-Lagrange equations are replaced by their mean values because the source terms in those equations increase with baryon density. Also, the coupling constants of the RMF models are density independent. There are other approaches where gross properties of dense matter relevant to neutron stars are calculated in the framework of nonrelativistic Brueckner-Hartree-Fock and variational chain summation (VCS) calculations using modern nucleon-nucleon interaction [18, 40, 41]. Recently, Akmal, Pandharipande and Ravenhall (APR) [18] have studied neutron star properties in the VCS method using a new Argonne V18subscriptğ‘‰18italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{18} nucleon-nucleon interaction (which fit all the data of the Nijmegen data base) with relativistic boost corrections and a fitted three-nucleon interaction. This calculation represents at present perhaps the most sophisticated many-body approach to dense matter. The bulk properties obtained in the APR model are binding energy E/B=16ğ¸ğµ16italic-E MULOP:divide italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:16E/B=16 MeV, nuclear symmetry energy aasy=33.94subscriptğ‘asy33.94italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start asy POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:33.94a_{\rm asy}=33.94 MeV, and incompressibility K=266ğ¾266italic-K RELOP:equals NUMBER:266K=266 MeV at a saturation density of n0=0.16subscriptğ‘›00.16italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.16n_{0}=0.16 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. To gauge the uncertainties involved in the extrapolation of the RMF model at high density, we compare the nucleons-only matter results with those of the APR model. For this purpose we use the model which contains nonlinear interaction for the scalar Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma-meson only. (Note that the TM1 model which includes also self-interaction of Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega-meson is fitted to finite nuclear properties.) The five parameters in this RMF model are fitted to the above mentioned (four) saturation properties plus the effective nucleon mass of mN*/mN=0.70subscriptsuperscriptğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘šğ‘0.70italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.70m^{*}_{N}/m_{N}=0.70 and 0.78 for the two representative cases considered here. In Fig. 13 we show the results for pure neutron matter (PNM) and symmetric nuclear matter (SNM) in the RMF model (solid lines), and in the APR model with pion condensation (dashed lines) and their low density extrapolations without a pion condensed phase (dotted lines) [18]. It is clear from this figure that the agreement between the two models breaks down at high density. The APR model takes into account possibly all leading many-body correlation effects. It was also demonstrated [18, 40] that the strong tensor correlation gives rise to neutral pion condensation in PNM and SNM at densities of 0.20 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} and 0.32 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}, respectively. The RMF model, however, cannot address the question of density dependent correlation in dense matter, and moreover the coupling constants are density independent. This may be crucial to the deviation of the RMF results from the APR calculations. Consequently, the threshold densities of antikaon condensation may be affected. On the other hand, the advantage of the RMF models is that relativity is in-built and this causes the EOS to be causal. However, in the APR model the EOS becomes superluminal at densities close to the maximum masses of the stars.

We have computed nucleons-only star masses using this parameter set in the RMF model. It was shown [42] that a neutron star may cool rapidly by the so-called direct URCA process in which neutrinos generated in the stars interior carry away the energy. The threshold density for this process depends on the symmetry energy which in turn is determined by the proton fraction. For the APR model the threshold is at a density of nB=0.78subscriptğ‘›ğµ0.78italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.78n_{B}=0.78 fm-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3} corresponding to a star of mass â‰ˆ2.0â¢MâŠ™absent2.0subscriptğ‘€direct-productRELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2.0 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\approx 2.0M_{\odot}. The relatively rapid rise of symmetry energy with density manifests in a smaller threshold density for the direct URCA process in the RMF models.

It may be worth mentioning that the role of nucleon-nucleon and kaon-nucleon correlations in kaon condensation in neutron star matter was studied by Pandharipande et al. [43]. The kaon energy for low density matter was calculated from Lenz potential while at high density the Hartree potential was used. The strong Nâ¢Nğ‘ğ‘italic-N italic-NNN and Kâ¢Nğ¾ğ‘italic-K italic-NKN correlations in the Hartree potential were shown to lead to a dramatic reduction of the antikaon attraction at high densities that could raise the threshold density for antikaon condensation to much higher values. Recently, kaon energy in neutron matter has been calculated analytically [44] by solving the Klein-Gordon equation in the Wigner-Seitz cell approximation. It was found that the transition from the low density Lenz potential to a high density Hartree potential occurs at âˆ¼4â¢n0similar-toabsent4subscriptğ‘›0RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4 italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sim 4n_{0}. However, in a chiral perturbation theory, Waas et al. [45] found that short-range correlations has only a moderate effect on the antikaon condensation densities.

IV Summary and Conclusions

We have investigated antikaon, K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-}- and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0}-meson, condensation in neutron stars within a relativistic mean field approach where the interaction between the baryons and antikaons are generated by the exchange of Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma, Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega, and ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho mesons. Three different parameter sets (GM1, TM1, and GMT) have been exploited in this calculation. In the GM1 and GMT sets the Lagrangian contain self-interaction for Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma-meson only, while the set TM1 incorporates also nonlinear interaction for Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega-meson. The softest nuclear equation of state follows from TM1 set whereas the stiffest one from GMT set. We find that the critical densities for K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and in particular KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensations depend sensitively on the choice of antikaon optical potential depth and more strongly on the nuclear equation of state. The threshold density of KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} always lie above that of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson. With the appearance of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates, the overall equation of state becomes softer compared to the situation without antikaon condensation. This leads to a reduction in the maximum star masses. With the softest EOS (TM1 set), KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensate may be formed inside maximum mass stars only when the KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical depth is quite large. On the other hand for the stiffest nuclear EOS (GMT set), KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} can occur well inside the maximum mass stars for rather small values of antikaon optical potential depth. The appearance of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson leads to a smaller variation of the vector fields with density. The decrease of KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} energy with density is therefore attenuated resulting in its formation at higher density than in the case when K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} meson is prohibited.

With the onset of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation (neglecting KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson), the proton fraction rises dramatically and even crosses the neutron fraction at some critical density. From the threshold conditions for K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} formations, i.e. Ï‰K-=Î¼n-Î¼psubscriptğœ”superscriptğ¾subscriptğœ‡ğ‘›subscriptğœ‡ğ‘italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{K^{-}}=\mu_{n}-\mu_{p} and Ï‰KÂ¯0=0subscriptğœ”superscriptÂ¯ğ¾00italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\omega_{\bar{K}^{0}}=0, it is evident that the critical point of identical proton and neutron densities (Fermi momenta) is precisely the density where KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} formation sets in. In earlier model studies of K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation only (where KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation were ignored), identical values of neutron and proton abundances were observed at high densities after K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} condensation. It may therefore be instructive to revisit the antikaon condensation scenario including KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} meson in these models. With the onset of KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensation, there is a competition in the formation of K--psuperscriptğ¾ğ‘italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-p{K^{-}}-p and KÂ¯0-nsuperscriptÂ¯ğ¾0ğ‘›OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\bar{K}^{0}}-n pairs resulting in a perfectly symmetric matter for nucleons and antikaons inside neutron stars. As the proton fraction is much enhanced in this situation, it may have profound implication on the cooling properties of neutron stars.

With the hyperon-meson couplings constants determined from hypernuclear data and Sâ¢Uâ¢(6)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ6italic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:)SU(6) symmetry relation, the hyperons are formed earlier than antikaons. Since the EOS becomes softer, antikaon condensation can only occur at high densities. The negatively charged hyperons cause a larger reduction in the electron chemical potential compared to that of the isovector potential. This indicates that in contrast to nucleons only stars, KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} has a higher formation probability in hyperonic stars, but only for relatively larger values of KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end\bar{K} optical potential depth.

For all the cases studied here, the maximum masses of the stars are found to be larger than the precise current observational lower limit of 1.44â¢MâŠ™1.44subscriptğ‘€direct-productNUMBER:1.44 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1.44M_{\odot} imposed by the larger mass of the binary pulsar PSR 1913 + 16 [46]. The recent discovery of high-frequency brightness oscillations in low-mass X-ray binaries provides a promising new avenue for determining masses and radii of neutron stars [47]. Large neutron star masses with an upper limit of Mâˆ¼2.0-2.3â¢MâŠ™similar-toğ‘€2.02.3subscriptğ‘€direct-productitalic-M RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2.0 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.3 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM\sim 2.0-2.3M_{\odot} have been extracted from kilohertz quasi-periodic-oscillations (QPO). The present investigation suggests that indeed both K-superscriptğ¾italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{-} and KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} condensates are possible in stars of such large masses. On the other hand, hyperon degrees of freedom which lower the maximum mass considerably, would be clearly excluded in these massive stars. In contrast, also very small masses of Mâ‰ˆ1.35Â±0.04â¢MâŠ™ğ‘€plus-or-minus1.350.04subscriptğ‘€direct-productitalic-M RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1.35 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.04 italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM\approx 1.35\pm 0.04M_{\odot} have been accurately determined in binary pulsars [48]. It is clear that exotic degrees of freedom like antikaons and hyperons must occur in these pulsars at few times the normal nuclear matter density.

It has been inferred that large magnetic field âˆ¼1018similar-toabsentsuperscript1018RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:18 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 10^{18}G could exist at the core of neutron stars [49]. Though such large interior field is not accessible to direct observation, their existence could influence certain gross properties of neutron stars, such as cooling properties of the stars [50]. Recently, there has been a considerable debate about whether a charged Bose gas in a constant magnetic field could exhibit a Bose-Einstein condensation [51, 52, 53, 54]. Some calculations ruled out such a possibility [51, 52] whereas others predicted that it could occur in a magnetic field [53, 54]. The formation of a Bose-Einstein condensate of neutral Bose gas such as a system of KÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğ¾0OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{K}^{0} in a strong magnetic field may be an interesting possibility.
